Award.AwardTitle: CGV: Large: Collaborative Research: Coupling Simulation and Mesh Generation using Computational Topology

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Many simulation algorithms depend on an underlying spatial discretization---a mesh that decomposes the domain into a finite set of elements that can be analyzed by a computer. The quality of the simulation is, in part, determined by the quality of the mesh. However, in the past, mesh generation and simulation were done as separate processes. Better results can be achieved by tightly integrating simulation with mesh generation and recent advices in computational topology provide the key to doing so. Computational topology allows for the analysis of the structure of data---in this case simulation variables. By understanding the structure of the simulation the mesh generation algorithms can adapt to it, providing meshes that are closely linked to the actual simulation.

Because simulation is a powerful tool for discovery throughout computational science, this research has the potential to have broad impact across all fields of science and enable new scientific breakthroughs that could have tremendous societal impact. This research will also produce open-source software, short courses, and workshops around the topic of coupling simulation and meshing. The interdisciplinary nature of this project will lead to a rich educational and research environment for graduate and undergraduate students. The project web site provides access to research results, software and educational materials (http://sealab.cs.utah.edu/SimulationMeshingTopology).

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has resulted in numerous refereed publications (2 edited books, 2 book chapters, 32 journal articles, 25 conference papers, and 6 theses and dissertations) on a wide variety of topics in simulation, meshing, and topology.   All of our publications and software are accessible from our project website: https://cal.cs.umbc.edu/SimulationMeshingTopology/

One particular focus or our research has been clustered shape matching, which we have demonstrated is a powerful technique for animating deformable bodies.  We have extending the initial work on clustered by incorporating plasticity, fracture, advanced clustering and re-clustering algorithms, and high-performance collision proxies.  We have also developed an example-based method for adding plastic deformation to rigid body animations, allowing for extremely efficient animation of failing materials.  In a similar vein we have developed a technique to add energy to rigid body fracture simulations, improving the realism of efficient animations of fracturing materials.  We have also explored animating fracture through the use of peridynamics simulation, a relatively new approach in the computational mechanics community.

The grant facilitated advances in simulation of coupled interactions of fluids and solids.  Such interactions occur on a wide variety of scales, from small-scale cytoplasmic flows in mitosis, to blood flow through the heart, internal combustion engines, and aircraft.  Simulation techniques are tailored to the specific material and physical phenomenon of interest, and when simulating multi-material systems as in fluid-structure interaction, it can be desirable to reuse existing systems optimized for each material, and combine them based on physical laws.  By developing novel coupling algorithms, our work allows a variety of fluid-structure interaction scenarios to be stably and robustly simulated through the reuse of existing solvers.  This facilitates ease of development, software reusability, and simulation of a broad range of coupled phenomena.

In the context of geometry and meshing we have developed techniques to extract surfaces from particle-based peridynamics simulations and a fast, frame-independent particle skinning method for animated particle data.

Much of our work has focused on researching new techniques for understanding the shape of data through topological analysis.  We have invested significant effort in improving these computations, both in terms of their numerical accuracy as well as their computational efficiency.  Furthermore, few public software tools existed prior to the grant beginning.  A major outcome of our efforts has been the development of many software artifacts to deliver topological analysis tools in the hands of scientists and application domains, including:  

- TTK (The Topology ToolKit): an open source framework to provide modules for scalar field analysis into the visualization tool ParaView 
- MSCEER: a software package for high-quality parallel topological reconstruction.  
- TopoMS: a software package for high-quality topological analysis for the quantum theory of atoms in molecules.  
- Babelflow: simplifying development of performance portable codes coupling analysis with complex simulation workflows.

These software packages have helped lead to scientific discoveries, by putting topological analysis tools in the hands of stakeholders.  As a result, we were also featured on the cover of the Journal of Computational Chemistry.

Broader Impact:
Our work has impacted a variety of domains that depend on computation.  In particular, both our techniques and software have integrated with aeronautical engineering, biomedical simulation, computational chemistry, and combustion.  These impacts have helped advanced the fundamental science questions that can be studied through scientific simulation.  This project has resulted in the training of many highly skilled personnel; 23 students and research staff have been trained through this project including 2 post-doctoral researchers, 12 PhD students, 7 MS students, and 2 undergraduates.  

Through outreach activities, we have helped educate broader audiences as well, impacting our communities directly.  We developed a SIGGRAPH course titled "An Introduction to Physics-based Animation."  Video of the course will appear as part of SIGGRAPH University and the course resulted in a comprehensive set of course notes and a slide deck that are available to educators and students.  Additionally, we have hosted tutorials and workshops that offer training for visualization techniques.

Finally, this project has resulted in the release of a number of open-source software projects, which can be accessed from the project website above.  These have impacted technology transfer and industry has adopted them as well.
